title: Women Still Underrepresented in Corporate Leadership
content: Despite making up nearly half of the workforce, women hold only 21% of C-suite positions in Fortune 500 companies. Of C-suite leaders today, 21% are women and just 1% are Black women. This persistent underrepresentation highlights the concrete ceiling that women of color face in corporate America.

title: Breaking Barriers: First Black Woman CEO at Major Tech Firm
content: In a historic milestone, Sarah Johnson became the first Black woman to lead a Fortune 100 technology company. Despite the systemic barriers that make it harder for women of color to reach executive positions, Johnson's appointment represents a significant breakthrough in diversifying corporate leadership.

title: White Men Continue to Dominate Executive Ranks
content: A new study reveals that White men remain overrepresented in leadership positions, holding 68% of senior executive roles despite comprising only 35% of the workforce. Meanwhile, men of color are hired at much lower rates compared to white men in the context of fulfilling CEO roles.

title: The Glass Ceiling vs The Concrete Ceiling
content: Whereas White women are up against a glass ceiling, Black women are up against a concrete ceiling. Research shows that Black women report experiencing intractable race-based stereotypes. They report their credibility and authority are called into question. They do not receive the type of institutional support they need.

title: Board Diversity: Progress and Challenges
content: Between 2016 and 2018, there were a total of 230 new board seats within Fortune 500 firms. Across these openings white women obtained 124, black women 32, asian women 17, and hispanic women only 4 seats. Some worry this is another way for white women to benefit from diversity efforts.
